Description.val:
The COMPASS CALL capability is the USAF's premier wide-area coverage Airborne Electronic Attack (AEA) Offensive Counter Information (OCI) weapon system. In order to ensure continued tactical effectiveness COMPASS CALL's Prime Mission Equipment (PME) must evolve to keep pace with emerging adversary developments in communications, radar, and sensor technology as well as the use of rapidly advancing commercial communications technology. To meet this challenge the COMPASS CALL program employs an incremental Baseline upgrade acquisition strategy that puts capability into the warfighter's hands as soon as practical and ensures each iteration of the weapon system is effective against the highest priority threats. A new Baseline of capability is fielded approximately every three years. Capabilities inserted into each Baseline are planned in advance, based on war-fighter inputs. Executive Management Reviews are held to review and "lock" Baseline content as production nears. Both modification kit components and integration costs for a given Baseline upgrade are procured in the first fiscal year (FY) of execution and installed the next year. Procurement funds are required for modification kit production (hardware, firmware, and software), installation, certification, and test on a re-host platform in accordance with the Baseline upgrade cyclic schedule.

As of first quarter FY 2018, the COMPASS CALL fleet consists of four (4) Baseline 1 (BL1) aircraft, eight (8) Mid-Baseline 2 (MBL2) aircraft, one (1) MBL2 test aircraft (on loan to the 55th Electronic Combat Group for training), and two (2) aircraft in depot receiving the MBL2 and Avionics Viability Program (AVP, a.k.a. glass cockpit) upgrade modifications. In addition to these aircraft the program also includes one (1) EC-130H Weapon System Trainer (WST, a.k.a. flight deck simulator) and two (2) COMPASS CALL Mission Crew Simulators (CCMCS). With each Baseline efforts focus on reliability and sustainability improvements, obsolescence replacement, weight reduction, simplification of PME operations and maintenance, and electronic attack capability increases.

At the beginning of FY 2017, with the transition to the Baseline 3 (BL3) re-host effort, the program of record added two (2) aircraft (will be known as EC-37B); one was procured in late FY 2017 and one will be procured in FY 2018. These two aircraft will receive upgraded PME from donor EC-130H aircraft. Procurement of the air vehicles for re-host is performed under the Aircraft Procurement, Air Force appropriation, Budget Activity 04, Budget Sub Activity 05 under P-1 Line Item Number: 10CALX/COMPASS CALL.

COMPASS CALL modification efforts include, but are not limited to, the Digital Narrow Band Subsystem; Counter Radar Subsystem; third generation Special Purpose Emitter Array (SPEAR) subsystem; and aircraft and PME retrofits. Baseline upgrades and enhancements will also include necessary support equipment, training device/simulator modifications, test and test support activities (planning, integration). The simulators provide for the training and qualification of aircrew and ground personnel as well as address training obsolescence issues. 

FY 2017 included $29.8M of Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) funding: $1.2M is included in the P-3A for Mod Number 1001 (COMPASS CALL) and $28.6M is included in in the P-3A for Mod Number 1003 (COMPASS CALL Baseline 3).

FY 2018 includes $56.720 of OCO funding: $23.7M is included in the P-3A for Mod Number 1001 (COMPASS CALL) and $33.0M is included in in the P-3A for Mod Number 1003 (COMPASS CALL Baseline 3).

FY 2019 includes $36.4M of OCO funding, included in the P-3A for Mod Number 1001 (COMPASS CALL).

Due to the rapidly changing threat environment encountered in overseas contingency operations, the acquisition program manager has the authority to redirect funding as necessary to meet currently stated and/or emerging Combatant Commander requirements through the integration of Quick Reaction Capability (QRC) kits and other high-priority efforts.

Funding for this exhibit is contained in PE 0207253F.

Justification.val: Where applicable, justification for individual modifications is provided in the P-3A exhibits.

Description.val:
The COMPASS CALL capability is the USAF's premier wide-area coverage Airborne Electronic Attack (AEA) Offensive Counter Information (OCI) weapon system. In order to ensure continued tactical effectiveness COMPASS CALL's Prime Mission Equipment (PME) must evolve to keep pace with emerging adversary developments in communications, radar, and sensor technology as well as the use of rapidly advancing commercial communications technology. To meet this challenge the COMPASS CALL program employs an incremental Baseline upgrade acquisition strategy that puts capability into the warfighter's hands as soon as practical and ensures each iteration of the weapon system is effective against the highest priority threats. A new Baseline of capability is fielded approximately every three years. Capabilities inserted into each Baseline are planned in advance, based on war-fighter inputs. Executive Management Reviews are held to review and "lock" Baseline content as production nears. Both modification kit components and integration costs for a given Baseline upgrade are procured in the first fiscal year (FY) of execution and installed the next year. Procurement funds are required for modification kit production (hardware, firmware, and software), installation, certification, and test on a re-host platform in accordance with the Baseline upgrade cyclic schedule.

As of first quarter FY 2018, the COMPASS CALL fleet consists of four (4) Baseline 1 (BL1) aircraft, eight (8) Mid-Baseline 2 (MBL2) aircraft, one (1) MBL2 test aircraft (on loan to the 55th Electronic Combat Group for training), and two (2) aircraft in depot receiving the MBL2 and Avionics Viability Program (AVP, a.k.a. glass cockpit) upgrade modifications. In addition to these aircraft the program also includes one (1) EC-130H Weapon System Trainer (WST, a.k.a. flight deck simulator) and two (2) COMPASS CALL Mission Crew Simulators (CCMCS). With each Baseline efforts focus on reliability and sustainability improvements, obsolescence replacement, weight reduction, simplification of PME operations and maintenance, and electronic attack capability increases.

COMPASS CALL modification efforts include, but are not limited to, the Digital Narrow Band Subsystem; Counter Radar Subsystem; and the third generation Special Purpose Emitter Array (SPEAR) subsystem. Procurement funds are also used for avionics modifications to meet Communications, Navigation, Surveillance/Air Traffic Management (CNS/ATM) requirements and address avionics obsolescence issues. Similarly, Baseline upgrades and enhancements will include necessary support equipment and training device/simulator modifications. The simulators replicate the fielded aircraft configurations, provide training and qualification of aircrew and ground personnel, and address training and certification obsolescence issues. Equipment includes aircraft and PME retrofits based on the inspection and modification cyclic schedule.

In FY 2017, Mod Number 1001 included $1.2M of the $29.8M total CALL00 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) funding. This $1.2M is for Automatic Dependent Surveillance Broadcast (ADS-B)/Mode-5 Identification Friend or Foe (IFF) transponder modifications as well as transmit patch panel capability enhancements allowing for rapid integration of Quick Reaction Capability (QRC) kits. This amount is included in the Other Government line. The remaining $28.6M is included in the P-3A for Mod Number 1003 (COMPASS CALL Baseline 3).

In FY2018, Mod Number 1001 includes $23.682M of the $56.720M total CALL00 OCO funding. This $23.682M is for ADS-B Out and Mode-5 IFF modifications to meet certain civil and NATO mandates (required to continue operations in restricted airspace across the globe as well as tactical employment) for the EC-130H fleet. Upgrades include the installation of ADS-B/Mode-5 transponders on eleven (11) aircraft. It also supports the upgrade of modern communications interception capabilities and avionics to ensure airspace access. This amount is included in the Other Government line. The remaining $33.0M is included in the P-3A for Mod Number 1003 (COMPASS CALL Baseline 3).

In FY2019, Mod Number 1001 includes $36.4M of OCO funding for Small Adaptive Bank of Electronic Resources (SABER) integration into the COMPASS CALL mission system to rapidly counter a continuously changing RF environment. SABER will consist of a Software Defined Radio (SDR) with multiple QRC software suites for specific missions and targets.

Due to the rapidly changing threat environment encountered in overseas contingency operations, the acquisition program manager has the authority to redirect funding as necessary to meet currently stated and/or emerging Combatant Commander requirements through the integration of Quick Reaction Capability (QRC) kits and other high-priority efforts.

Funding for this exhibit is contained in PE 0207253F.

Milestone/Development Status

The COMPASS CALL weapon system is continuously improved using a rapid development and acquisition process supporting a Baseline upgrade strategy. User needs and technology opportunities are continuously reviewed and a new PME Baseline is defined approximately every 60 months. By the third quarter of FY 2018, ten (10) PMAI EC-130H COMPASS CALL aircraft will be in the Mid Baseline 2 configuration.

The COMPASS CALL capability is the USAF's premier wide-area coverage Airborne Electronic Attack (AEA) Offensive Counter Information (OCI) weapon system. In order to ensure continued tactical effectiveness COMPASS CALL's Prime Mission Equipment (PME) must evolve to keep pace with emerging adversary developments in communications, radar, and sensor technology as well as the use of rapidly advancing commercial communications technology. To meet this challenge the COMPASS CALL program employs an incremental Baseline upgrade acquisition strategy that puts capability into the warfighter's hands as soon as practical and ensures each iteration of the weapon system is effective against the highest priority threats. A new Baseline of capability is fielded approximately every three years. Capabilities inserted into each Baseline are planned in advance, based on war-fighter inputs. Executive Management Reviews are held to review and "lock" Baseline content as production nears. Both modification kit components and integration costs for a given Baseline upgrade are procured in the first fiscal year (FY) of execution and installed the next year. Procurement funds are required for modification kit production (hardware, firmware, and software) to include software integration lab components, installation, certification, and test on a re-host platform in accordance with the Baseline upgrade cyclic schedule.

As of first quarter FY 2018, the COMPASS CALL fleet consists of four (4) Baseline 1 (BL1) aircraft, eight (8) Mid-Baseline 2 (MBL2) aircraft, one (1) MBL2 test aircraft (on loan to the 55th Electronic Combat Group for training), and two (2) aircraft in depot receiving the MBL2 and Avionics Viability Program (AVP, a.k.a. glass cockpit) upgrade modifications. In addition to these aircraft the program also includes one (1) EC-130H Weapon System Trainer (WST, a.k.a. flight deck simulator) and two (2) COMPASS CALL Mission Crew Simulators (CCMCS). With each Baseline efforts focus on reliability and sustainability improvements, obsolescence replacement, weight reduction, simplification of PME operations and maintenance, and electronic attack capability increases.

At the beginning of FY 2017, with the transition to the Baseline 3 (BL3) re-host effort, the program of record added two (2) aircraft (will be known as EC-37B); one was procured in late FY 2017 and one will be procured in FY 2018. These two aircraft will receive upgraded PME from donor EC-130H aircraft. Procurement of the air vehicles for re-host is performed under the Aircraft Procurement, Air Force appropriation, Budget Activity 04, Budget Sub Activity 05 under P-1 Line Item Number: 10CALX/COMPASS CALL. Procurement and installation of the BL3 PME modification kits onto those air vehicles is performed under this line item (CALL00/Modification Number 1003).

COMPASS CALL modification efforts include, but are not limited to, the Digital Narrow Band Subsystem; Counter Radar Subsystem; third generation Special Purpose Emitter Array (SPEAR) subsystem; and aircraft and PME retrofits. Baseline upgrades and enhancements will also include necessary support equipment, training device/simulator modifications, test and test support activities (planning, integration). The simulators provide for the training and qualification of aircrew and ground personnel as well as address training obsolescence issues. 

In FY 2017, Mod Number 1003 included $28.6M of the $29.8M total CALL00 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) funding. This $28.6M of funding is for SPEAR Generation 3 capability and is included in the Group B kit procurement line. The remaining $1.2M is included in the P-3A for Mod Number 1001 (COMPASS CALL).

In FY 2018, Mod Number 1003 includes $33.0M of the $56.720M total CALL00 OCO funding. This funding is for SPEAR Generation 3 capability and is included in the Group B kit procurement line. The remaining $23.682M is included in the P-3A for Mod Number 1001 (COMPASS CALL).

The FY 2017 Group B Kit line item includes two (2) Group B kits. The second Group B kit procurement was appropriated in the FY 2017 Request for Additional Appropriation (RAA). This kit is for EC-37B aircraft #2. The Group B amount in FY 2018 is for the SPEAR Generation 3 capability identified in the OCO paragraph above, and in FY2019 is for the third EC-37B aircraft. The third EC-37B air vehicle is funded in the FY 2019, Aircraft Procurement, Air Force appropriation, Budget Activity 04, Budget Sub Activity 05, under P-1 Line Item Number: 10CALX/COMPASS CALL.

Due to the rapidly changing threat environment encountered in overseas contingency operations, the acquisition program manager has the authority to redirect funding as necessary to meet currently stated and/or emerging Combatant Commander requirements through the integration of Quick Reaction Capability (QRC) kits and other high-priority efforts.

Funding for this exhibit is contained in PE 0207253F.

Milestone/Development Status

The COMPASS CALL weapon system is continuously improved using a rapid development and acquisition process supporting a Baseline upgrade strategy. User needs and technology opportunities are continuously reviewed and a new mission equipment Baseline is defined approximately every 36 months. The COMPASS CALL Baseline 3 configuration will begin initial fielding in 2022.
